snippet.textDisplay:
First of all, as many others have pointed out, you wrap the tampon in toilet paper before discarding it (or if you're using a pad, in the cover the new one comes in). When I'm out and about and I'm not sure of the bin in toilet situation I always bring a poop bag for dogs. That way I can safely put my tampon in the toilet paper and then in the bag and no one will notice.

Secondly, period cups isn't for everyone. Don't know how many girls that have told me what a life saver they are and how I can live without them. It doesn't work for me. It's not comfortable, and if I get a smaller size it doesn't hold up for my heavy flow. Please stop with the whole "Once you use them you never will look back". It's great that they are such a life saver for you, but they aren't for everyone
snippet.textOriginal:
First of all, as many others have pointed out, you wrap the tampon in toilet paper before discarding it (or if you're using a pad, in the cover the new one comes in). When I'm out and about and I'm not sure of the bin in toilet situation I always bring a poop bag for dogs. That way I can safely put my tampon in the toilet paper and then in the bag and no one will notice.

Secondly, period cups isn't for everyone. Don't know how many girls that have told me what a life saver they are and how I can live without them. It doesn't work for me. It's not comfortable, and if I get a smaller size it doesn't hold up for my heavy flow. Please stop with the whole "Once you use them you never will look back". It's great that they are such a life saver for you, but they aren't for everyone

snippet.textDisplay: You wrap the pad/tampon in tissue or the wrapper of the new one and put it in the bin or you can get/make a pocket meant for reusable pads and wrap them up in there until you are able to get rid of it cleanly .  The finger covers are meant to be rolled on and off like a condom.  The pants are for us heavy flow folks that will overflow other products super easy. And yeah, don't stick things that used to be alive up your jayjay, the risk of bacteria and mold is way too high.
snippet.textOriginal: You wrap the pad/tampon in tissue or the wrapper of the new one and put it in the bin or you can get/make a pocket meant for reusable pads and wrap them up in there until you are able to get rid of it cleanly .  The finger covers are meant to be rolled on and off like a condom.  The pants are for us heavy flow folks that will overflow other products super easy. And yeah, don't stick things that used to be alive up your jayjay, the risk of bacteria and mold is way too high.

snippet.textDisplay: I love my period undies. Look at the brand Thinx unsure if it is only available in the US though. Those you don’t wear with anything and are great for my heavy days. They do have different levels of heaviness depending on your flow. They have thongs for light days and then I have the boy shorts. Only downside is what type of outter pants you can wear with the boy shorts because they are a little bulky. I also have a bunch of reusable pads which are handmade. I assume the Thinx could leak if someone’s flow is tooooo heavy. To wash you rinse out all blood complete, I let air dry and then throw in the wash with cold water and the rest of my clothes and then only air dry. Thinx have a special material in them that can’t be dried. The reusable pads I just air dry to keep them nicer. 💕💕
snippet.textOriginal: I love my period undies. Look at the brand Thinx unsure if it is only available in the US though. Those you don’t wear with anything and are great for my heavy days. Since everybody is talking about disposing toilet paper and tampons and pads...
Just a quick reminder: not all countries dispose their toilet paper inside the toilet! Here in Brazil our toilet paper is not meant to go down the toilet!

snippet.textDisplay: I don't use tampons anymore as I now use a menstral cup (so much better, imo) and use reusable pads to bed - but when I used tampons I always flushed (no idea you couldn't, I thought they were designed to be flushed, like flushable wipes) and if staying round a friend's for the night and having to dispose of my pad, I would wrap in the plastic packaging it came in and sometimes, if I had a heavy flow, I would take those purple lavender scented bags with me, so the dry blood wouldn't start to smell. Now that I use reusable pads, all I need to take with me is a wet bag to put my used pads in to wash when I get home - so I don't need to put anything in the bin - which means no extra plastic bag - it's so much better for the environment! It's also so much cheaper for me
snippet.textOriginal: I don't use tampons anymore as I now use a menstral cup (so much better, imo) and use reusable pads to bed - but when I used tampons I always flushed (no idea you couldn't, I thought they were designed to be flushed, like flushable wipes) and if staying round a friend's for the night and having to dispose of my pad, I would wrap in the plastic packaging it came in and sometimes, if I had a heavy flow, I would take those purple lavender scented bags with me, so the dry blood wouldn't start to smell. Now that I use reusable pads, all I need to take with me is a wet bag to put my used pads in to wash when I get home - so I don't need to put anything in the bin - which means no extra plastic bag - it's so much better for the environment! snippet.textDisplay:
Jazzy. I've been watching your videos for years now. I find you so bubbly and inviting to watch. I'm now a mother, my baby girl is asleep next to me and this video just makes my heart sing for mums of teen girls. These are not the easiest conversions for young girls, but how nice for them to have a mentor online to speak frankly about something so natural.

Also, period panties need to be washed a few times to increase absorbency. (same for cloth nappies if you ever decide to do that 😉).

snippet.textDisplay:
I used those sea sponges for a while many years ago and they were okay. Obviously not recommending anyone go out and buy one without doing their research, just putting it out there that they were reasonably effective and comfortable. You do get blood on your fingers like with a menstrual cup and personally I don’t trust them 100% to catch everything, especially if you have a heavy flow (but if your flow is too light, it hurts to get them in).

I don’t get periods anymore thanks to birth control but when I did, I’d use tampons and reusable pads, or just reusable pads if I had a very light flow. The idea of reusable pads squicks some people out, but you wash them; the concept is the same as menstrual cups or sponges, but way more comfortable and you get cute patterns. You get different sizes and... strengths? lol. The nighttime one was a lifesaver as a teen, saved my sheets and underwear. Like I said, they can be backup if you wear tampons or used alone.

So even if the sponge is safe (remember tampons can also cause toxic shock if used incorrectly!) I think there are better options out there.
snippet.textOriginal:

I don’t get periods anymore thanks to birth control but when I did, I’d use tampons and reusable pads, or just reusable pads if I had a very light flow. The idea of reusable pads squicks some people out, but you wash them; the concept is the same as menstrual cups or sponges, but way more comfortable and you get cute patterns. You get different sizes and... strengths? lol. The nighttime one was a lifesaver as a teen, saved my sheets and underwear. Like I said, they can be backup if you wear tampons or used alone. 

So even if the sponge is safe (remember tampons can also cause toxic shock if used incorrectly!) I think there are better options out there.

snippet.textDisplay: With the first product, the lube is probably what caused it to be hydrophobic in the beginning. Once you insert it, the lube will get dissolved helping to prevent that issue. Also, when you are on your period, your uterus and vaginal canal have micro spasms that most people are unaware of, excluding cramps, that push the lining and blood out of the body. So the sponge would be getting “squidged” by that process alone.
snippet.textOriginal: With the first product, the lube is probably what caused it to be hydrophobic in the beginning. Once you insert it, the lube will get dissolved helping to prevent that issue. Also, when you are on your period, your uterus and vaginal canal have micro spasms that most people are unaware of, excluding cramps, that push the lining and blood out of the body. So the sponge would be getting “squidged” by that process alone.

snippet.textDisplay: Just for future reference... The usual amount of blood loss per full 4-7 day period is 10 to 35 ml. Each soaked normal-sized tampon or pad holds a teaspoon (5ml) of blood .
snippet.textOriginal: Just for future reference... The usual amount of blood loss per full 4-7 day period is 10 to 35 ml. Each soaked normal-sized tampon or pad holds a teaspoon (5ml) of blood .

snippet.textDisplay: People have already mentioned how they dispose of pads and tampons by wrapping them in the next product's packaging and/or toilet paper, but as someone who cleaned public bathrooms, I can confirm a human removes the used menstrual products from the bin (and, at least in the US, in ladies' bathrooms there are special bins just for disposing of these items to prevent flushing). And yes, it can be unpleasant, but it had to be done. 😆
snippet.textOriginal: People have already mentioned how they dispose of pads and tampons by wrapping them in the next product's packaging and/or toilet paper, but as someone who cleaned public bathrooms, I can confirm a human removes the used menstrual products from the bin (and, at least in the US, in ladies' bathrooms there are special bins just for disposing of these items to prevent flushing). And yes, it can be unpleasant, but it had to be done. 😆

snippet.textOriginal: Uhm, who present day looked at a sea sponge and was like yep, I want to use that as a tampon. No way José. And yes,you said absorbency correctly ❤

snippet.textDisplay: I've been a vivid tampon and pads/liners user. For disposing of these objects when toileting out and about I wrap them in toilet paper and then throw them in the bin. Either in a bin located at the restroom or elsewhere. It can be a bit embarrassing especially at a friends house.

snippet.textDisplay:
You know those sanitary bins with paper bags in them in toilet stalls... YOURE NOT MEANT TO LEAVE YOUR PRODUCTS IN THEM!!

Drove me nuts when I was a cleaner. You take a bag out, put your product in it, and then put the bag in the regular bin

snippet.textDisplay: Loveeeedddd Loveeeeddddd the video...its good to see something out of the box yet informative......❤❤
